of Ten Thousand other different Minerals, all Originally, whilst 
in a soft and fluid State tending towards the Centre. It must 
Mechanically and almost necessarily follow by ye continuall 
Revolution of the Crude Mass from West to East, like the winding 
up of a Jack, or rolling up the Leaves of a Paper Book, that every 
one of these <u>Strata<\u> tho they each reach the Centre, must in
some place or other appear to the Day, in which Case there 
needs no Specifick Gravitation to cause the lightest to be up=
=permost &ca. for every one in its Turn in Some place of the 
Globe or other will be uppermost; And were it practicable to 
sink to the Centre of the Earth, all the Strata that are would 
be found in every Part and according to the Poet, Ponderibus Libra=
=ta suis. Add to this that in all Places within my knowledge,
the Observation of x another Member of the Society has held 
good, that the Precipices of all Hills are to the Westward, whereas 
the ascent to the East is more graduall; The farther Enquiry into 
which I offer to the Curious who have better Oppertunity. Isha 
only hint farther to such as have an Astronomicall Genius 
that possibly the Motion of the Earth may receive some 
Confirmation from the forementioned Situation of the Strata 
of Coal and other Minerals & especially if found uniform in 
Different parts of the Earth. For if the foresd. Position of the severall 
Strata and Ascents of hills is mechanically accounted for, by 
the supposed Motion of the Earth from West to East whilst the Earth 
was soft and tender, the said Motion of the Earth is reciprocally 
the necessary Result of all these Facts, And is therefore itself an 
undoubted fact. But this is an Hint of such Importance as to 
deserve a more exact Research.

x Dr. Shihely
